author: liberosist
content:
Also, given rollups always have a failsafe state on L1, they can be a lot more aggressive with state size management tech like state expiry, potentially with shorter expiry periods. It'd be a great place to battle-test state expiry before being implemented on L1. With a sequence of state diffs, you can pretty much reconstruct what you need directly from L1, and with zkRollups these techniques can be further refined. Also, with validity proofs, the burden of users verifying on commodity hardware is eliminated - instead of multiple potential disputers, you just need to have a coordination mechanism for sequencers/provers. Hermez, for example, is using sequencer auctions. It's acceptable for the sequencer/prover to run a high-spec machine in the limited time that it has bid for. (There could be better coordination mechanisms with proof-of-stake, of course.) L1 will reject invalid state transitions, and users can verify valid commitments directly from L1. You'll see techniques that'll enable them to directly operate over L1. (See: https://ethresear.ch/t/future-proof-shard-and-history-access-precompiles/9781). Finally, there'll always be a withdrawal mechanism from L1 - hopefully we see light withdrawals with zkRs. Each rollup can go much further than any L1 can securely, and there can be multiple rollups over L1. 

What's the other option? You get Solana, which in less than a year it's already impossible to sync a full node from genesis, so you have to rely on snapshots from Solana Labs - a centralized entity. Rollups may run in the same problem as Solana, sure, but you can construct a snapshot from Ethereum - a decentralized network. Not to mention I expect rollups, as mentioned above, to implement better state size management techniques, rather relying on sheer brute force like Solana does.
